data.title: Great Feast of the Holy Ghost opening Thursday
authors: Lurdes Da Silva  Ojornal Editor, Fall River Herald News
data.meta_description: Check out the four-day schedule of events planned for this year's feast.
data.text:
FALL RIVER - José Silva says the Holy Ghost has touched his life in many ways.

“It’s always been in my heart, and it has always been an integral part of my life,” said Silva, who is at the helm of this year’s Great Feast of the Holy Ghost of New England.

Born in Rabo de Peixe, S. Miguel, Azores, Silva was a teenager when he arrived in Fall River via Canada in 1967.

“My family has served in my hometown’s feast for four generations, and I hope my children can carry on that tradition,” he said.

Despite the distance from his motherland, his devotion to the Holy Spirit grew even fonder and Silva said the Great Feast has helped him remain rooted to his Portuguese heritage.

“I have been a member of the feast committee for a few years, but this is my first time as its president. It’s such a great honor and I am very humbled by it,” said the Dartmouth resident, who served as the feast’s vice-president in 2012 and 2013.

Silva said that one of his goals as president has been to encourage greater participation and collaboration from the Brotherhoods and the youth.

“The youth are the future of this feast,” he said. “It’s very important that one day they carry it on, as it is a celebration of our faith and culture.”

Silva said he is appreciative of all the untiring and unseen tasks undertaken by an anonymous army of volunteers who work diligently to assure the success of each celebration.

“They work tirelessly for months,” said Silva. “You can’t have a successful feast without them. But we need everyone’s support.”

One of the committee’s greatest challenges has always been the fundraising aspect, as the four-day celebration comes with a roughly $180,000 price tag.

“The feast by itself does not cover the expenses,” said Silva noting that some of those expenses include permit fees, rental of Kennedy Park, and the electricity bill. “That’s why sponsorships are so important.”

Silva knows a thing or two about fundraising as he has been actively involved in several community initiatives. He was part of the Amigos de Rabo de Peixe, Inc.- USA for several years, and served as their president from 2005 to 2007.

He then founded the Irmandade do Senhor Bom Jesus da Vila de Rabo de Peixe-USA (Brotherhood of the Good Lord Jesus of the Vila de Rabo de Peixe-USA) in 2007, and currently serves as its president. He also serves as president of the General Assembly of the Saint Anthony Band of Fall River.

“I hope everyone comes out to support the Great Feast,” he said. “It’s a great showing of our rich cultural and religious heritage.”

If you go

AUG. 21 (Thursday)

7:00 PM — Opening of the festivities at Kennedy Park.

7:15 PM — Entertainment by local community entertainers:

7:30 PM — 2FK

7:30 – 8 PM — Geana Soares

8 – 8:30 PM — Catia Ferreira

8:30 – 9 PM — Rosa Maria

9 – 10 PM — Shirley Guerreiro

10 – 10:45 PM — Nádia & Band

11:00 PM — Closing

AUG. 22 (FRIDAY)

7 PM — Blessing of the food (Pensões) to be distributed amongst the needy. The act will be presided by Bishop Manuel da Silva Rodrigues Linda, Military Ordinariate of Portugal, with other dignitaries attending.

7:30 PM — Inauguration of Arts and Crafts Fair, featuring artisans from the Azores and regional products.

7:45 PM — Performance by the Folia from the Our Lady of Rosary Church of East Providence. The Folia is a traditional group of singers and musicians who play songs in honor of the Holy Ghost.

9:00 PM — Auction

9:30 – 10:45 PM — Entertainment provided by José Nazário and his band.

11:00 PM — Closing

AUG. 23 (SATURDAY)

9:30 AM — Ethnographic Parade and Bodo de Leite” departing from the Ponta Delgada Boulevard to Kennedy Park, via Columbia and South Main streets.

At the conclusion of the parade, sweet bread and milk will be distributed to all present at Kennedy Park.

2:00 PM- 4 PM — Festival of Folklore with several groups from the USA and abroad:

2:00 PM — Rancho Folclórico Sonhos de Portugal, New Jersey

2:30 PM — Rancho Folclórico Camponeses do Minho, New Jersey

3 PM — Rancho Folclórico Portugal Norte a Sul, New Jersey

3:30 PM — Grupo Folclórico da Imaculada Coração de Maria, Connecticut

4 PM — Rancho Folclórico da Casa dos Açores de Quebec, Montreal, Canada

4:00 PM – 5:30 PM — Auction to benefit the Feast

6 – 7:30 PM — Concert by Santa Cecília Band of Fall River

Entertainment by local community entertainers:

7:30 - 8:30 PM — Maurício Morais

8:30 – 9:30 PM — Michelle Romeiro

9:30 – 10:45 PM — Luís Neves and his band

11:00 PM — Closing

AUG. 24 (SUNDAY)

12 PM — Solemn Mass and Coronation at Saint Anne’s Church, co-celebrated by Bishop Manuel da Silva Rodrigues Linda of Portugal, and the Most Rev. George W. Coleman, Bishop of Fall River.

2 PM — Procession of Coronation starting at St. Anne’s Church, featuring numerous Holy Ghost Brotherhoods of the United States and abroad, Philharmonic Bands and all honored guests and dignitaries, including Bishop Linda;Ana Luísa Pereira Luís, President of the Legislative Assembly of the Autonomous Region of Azores; Paulo Teves, Regional Director for the Azorean communities; Ricardo Farias, representing the Community; Mayor William Flanagan of Fall River, Portuguese Consul Pedro Carneiro, Maria João Ávila, member of the Portuguese Parliament, and other religious, civil and political leaders.

5 PM — 6: 30 PM — Concerts by Saint Anthony Band of Fall River and Senhor da Pedra Band of New Bedford.

6:30 PM – 7 PM— Auction to benefit the Feast

7 PM – 8: 30 PM — Concert by Irmãos Justino.

8 PM — Raffle Drawing and closing remarks by Committee President José Silva.

8:15 PM — 9:45 PM — Concert by Jorge Ferreira and his band.

10 PM — Closing
